awd_titl_txt: AGS-FIRP Track 1: Undergraduate Field Experience in Atmospheric Chemistry at the Storm Peak Laboratory in Spring 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide funding for a 3-day field-based research experience at the Storm Peak Laboratory (SPL). SPL is a Community Instruments & Facilities (CIF) site supported by the NSF Facilities for Atmospheric Research and Education (FARE) program. Sixteen undergraduate students from Colorado College, which is a Primarily Undergraduate Institution (PUI), will participate. These participants will be students enrolled in an upper-division elective course for Environmental Science majors at Colorado College. The overall goal of this field-based course component is to provide a diverse group of Colorado College undergraduate students majoring in Environmental Science or related subjects with an experiential learning opportunity in atmospheric chemistry. 

Students participating in the project will be introduced to core facets of the scientific research process, including research question development, field study design, measurement techniques, data analysis, and synthesis of information. A major outcome of this course will be to aid in the preparation of undergraduate Environmental Science and other science, technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) majors at Colorado College for their post-graduation career paths. The proposed project will also contribute to the development of a globally competitive STEM workforce and improved STEM education by providing an educational opportunity that enables students to gain experience and professional skills in environmental instrumentation, field-program design and execution, scientific collaboration, and scientific communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the creation of a week-long field course in Atmospheric Chemistry for undergraduate Environmental Science majors at the Storm Peak Laboratory (SPL) in Steamboat Springs, CO during March 2023. The course was leveraged by a prior research collaboration between the project investigators, Drs. Lynne Gratz and A. Gannet Hallar, that involved continuous atmospheric measurements of trace gases, aerosols, meteorology, and mercury at SPL. The student field experience was part of a regular 3.5-week course block at Colorado College, a primarily undergraduate institution in Colorado Springs, CO. The course learning goals were for students to:

  • connect course concepts to the natural world and to practical research questions;
  • gain field experience outside the classroom and in a world class research facility;
  • develop data analysis methods to address a specific research question;
  • engage in the collaborative research process, with classmates and professional scientists;
  • present results, orally and in writing, to enhance scientific communication skills.

Students spent the first two weeks of the course on campus learning fundamental concepts in tropospheric and stratospheric chemistry, while also engaging with primary literature from SPL and other mountaintop atmospheric observatories. They also carried out laboratory assignments designed to build analytical skills, such as air mass transport modeling and graphical or statistical methods, that would later underpin their final course projects. While at SPL, students learned about laboratory operations, instrumental methods, and sampling design while also making measurements of the local atmosphere. Students then devised final research projects centered on the quality-assured data generated from the co-PIs’ aforementioned collaborative research project, which they summarized in oral in-class presentations (with co-PI Hallar in virtual attendance) and written extended abstracts to complete the course. Throughout the course, careful efforts were taken to ensure an inclusive, safe, engaging, and impactful learning experience for all participants. This field experience demonstrated a unique opportunity to broaden the undergraduate learning experience through the application of course concepts at an internationally-renowned atmospheric research station in collaboration with scholars from research-oriented institutions.
